results.title: Jericho
results.creator_credit: Thornton Freeland, Walter Futter and Buckingham
results.brief_description: In France 1917, heroic corporal Jericho Jackson accidently kills his abusive seargent. He is charged with the murder but escapes from military prison leaving his friend Captain Mack behind to face a five year prison sentence after being accused of assisting his escape. When Captain Mack is released in 1922, he vows to track down and capture Jericho who has by this time has made a home for himself in North Africa, practicing medicine and uniting the disparate Arab tribes on the annual salt caravan. When Mack finally confronts Jericho, has difficulty destroying the life he has built. Stars Paul Robeson, Henry Wilcoxon, Wallace Ford, John Laurie, Princess Kouka. Paul Robeson sings several songs including ‘Brother are you going my way?’.

results.title: The Agony and the ecstasy
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on Irving Stone’s mammoth bestseller, “The Agony and the Ecstasy” is the dynamic retelling of one of the fiercest and most productive collaborations in art history, that of artist and painter Michelangelo, and the man who commissioned him to paint the Sistine Chapel, Pope Julius II. As played by Charlton Heston (as the painter) and Rex Harrison (as the Pope), the men are both titanic egoists determined to leave eternity a unique vision of their love and faith for God. Though “the Agony and the Ecstasy” betrays an earlier era’s reluctance to deal with either Michelangelo’s ambivalent sexuality, or the Pope’s lustful material excesses, the emotionally violent duels between the men betray the deep extremes of hatred, jealousy and love which dominated their relationship. For a contemporary viewer it is the richly colourful cinematography and the epic reconstruction of Renaissance Rome which is the film’s long-lasting legacy. If the melodrama of the clashes between the tortured artist and the meglomaniac Pope now seem almost camp, the recreation of the feat of painting the vast Chapel still seems wondrous. Cast also includes Diane Cilento, Harry Andrews and Alberto Lupo.

results.title: Looking for Alibrandi [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Robyn Kershaw, AFFC, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Premium Movie Partnership
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by first time writer Melina Marchetta, “Looking for Alibrandi” is an affectionate look at three generations of strong willed Italian women, and the youngest member, Josie’s (Pia Miranda) attempt to break the family “curse”. 17 year old Josie lives with her single mother Christina (Greta Scacchi), is completing her HSC at an exclusive Sydney school on a scholarship, begrudgingly visiting her Nonna, defending the labels of “wog” and “bastard”, and longing after the lifestyle afforded to rich kids with both parents. When her father, Michael (Anthony La Paglia) enters their lives again, Josie confronts her mother and her Nonna about the rift between Christina and her father, and the animosity between mother and daughter to reveal secrets long since hidden. Josie must also make decisions about her future career and what her heart desires as she is torn between school captain John Barton (Matthew Newton) and public school boy Jacob (Kick Gurry). Between work, school, family and personal relationships, Josie discovers that life is filled with uncertainty and she is not the only one debilitated by the labels society ascribes. This was the first feature film effort for both director Woods and actor Miranda. Remarkably, the film was nominated and won several AFI awards, including best film, best supporting actress (Scacchi) and best performance by an actress in a leading role (Miranda).

results.title: The Magic sword: quest for Camelot
results.creator_credit: Frederick DuChan, Dalisa Cohen and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in the time of King Arthur, a renegade knight sets out to seize power by stealing the sword Excalibur. Brave Hayley, who longs to become a knight, sets out together with a young blind hermit, a dragon and a falcon, to foil his plot, recover the magic sword, and save the kingdom. Featuring the voices of Cary Elwes, Gary Oldman, Eric Idle, Pierce Brosnan and Sir John Gielgud.

results.title: The Matrix
results.creator_credit: Lana Wachowski, Lilly Wachowski, Andrew Mason, Joel Silver and Silver Pictures
results.brief_description: The Question that drives us all - What is the Matrix? “Do you believe in fate?” “No, I don’t like to know that I am not in control of my life” “You feel that something is wrong but you don’t know what it is. The world that has been pulled over your eyes, that is to blind you to the Truth. I am offering you “The Truth” - nothing more”. These are the questions at the beginning of a film which stretches the imagination, makes you contemplate your own reality and sense of self. Just like Alice in Wonderland following the white rabbit, so too do we follow Neo (Keanu Reeves) to a new and different reality led by Morpheus (Laurence Fishburne). Along this path we meet Trinity (Carrie-Anne Moss), Switch, Cypher (Joe Pantoliano), The Oracle (Gloria Foster) and the ubiquitous Agent Smith (Hugo Weaving), all who assist/interact with Neo to make sense of the original question - What is The Matrix? No-one can conceive it, no-one can be told what it is. It has to be seen to be understood. This is the new breed of Sci-Fi film, and just as “2001” reinvented the genre back in 1968, “The Matrix” has added to this model. From the 26 minute “Making of” doco following the feature, we are privy to some of the actors insights such as - “It has individual style and visual effects”, “Robots versus Kung Fu”, “Action Adventure, a film which gives flesh to an idea or Cyber-Punk cartoon that provides Hope, Love and Belief, even as I believe that belief is sometimes suspended”. We also learn that the principle actors worked for 6 months learning Kung Fu from fight co-ordinator and Kung Fu Master, Yuen Wa Ping and his team prior to beginning production.

results.title: Lock, stock and two smoking barrels [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn, Ska Films and Summit Entertainment
results.brief_description: When four small time London cons pool their savings for a high-rolling illegal card game with local crime boss Hatchet Harry, things don’t quite go as confidently anticipated. The four friends end up owing him half a million pounds with only a week to pay it off under threat of systematic loss of fingers if they fail to do so. As they engage in robbery, deception and double crossing involving their criminal next door neighbours, powerful drug barons and Harry himself to get the money, circumstances spiral surrealistically out of their control. The situation is further complicated by confusion over two valuable antique guns that Hatchet Harry has purchased, and which are mistakenly directed for use in pulling a ‘job’. The four hapless friends muddle through the seedy underside of London and an unwittingly created gang war in a collection of comic moments and misunderstandings balanced seamlessly with more serious elements. This is a tightly structured film with a cleverly twisted plot and striking rhythmic visuals and editing that, combined with the soundtrack, can be likened to the best of music videos. Cast includes Jason Flemyng, Dexter Fletcher, Nick Moran, Jason Stratham and Steven Mackintosh.

results.title: Better than chocolate
results.creator_credit: Anne Wheeler, Sharon McGowan, British Columbia Film, Race Films and Telefilm Canada
results.brief_description: Maggie has flunked law school and is working for uptight Frances, who runs a gay bookshop in Vancouver. Kim is a van-dwelling artist. When they meet it is love at first sight. To avoid confrontation with her mother, Maggie makes up a success story and tells her that she’s living in a beautiful apartment ( she is - it’s just that she’s housesitting for a woman who runs Safer Sex With Latex workshops). Just at their relationship is blossoming Maggie learns that her mother and brother (who have no idea about her sexuality) are planning to come and stay with her. This confronting movie is about the problems young lesbians experience coming out and facing their parents (and society) and realizing that in the long run being a lesbian is not the worst problem one can have.

results.title: The Sixth sense
results.creator_credit: M Night Shyamalan, Barry Mendel, Frank Marshall, Kathleen Kennedy and Spyglass Entertainment
results.brief_description: This low key supernatural thriller harks back to the days of Val Lewton and Jacques Tourneur’s creepy horror films (“Cat people”, “The Leopard man”, “I walked with a zombie”) where the power of suggestion reigned and a mere shadow would have you jumping in your seat. So too does “The Sixth sense” manage to create that feeling of unknowable dread and terror. The film’s opening sets the mood of unease when renowned child psychologist Dr. Malcolm Crowe (Bruce Willis) is accosted in his home by a disturbed ex-client. Flash forward one year and Dr. Crowe is trying to mend the past by helping a new patient, who shares similar traits to his assailant. The patient is Cole Sear (Joel Haley Osment), a troubled young boy who lives his life in constant fear. Why he is scared all the time is one of the many creepy surprises this film holds. What could have easily been a substandard supernatural thriller is elevated by writer, director M. Night Shyamalan and his fine cast (which includes Toni Collette who shines in an all too brief supporting role), all of them showing a quiet restraint which pays off brilliantly in the film’s more frightening moments. Cast also includes Olivia Williams. (Note: This video features 9 minutes of bonus footage not seen in the theatrical release, including an extended ending.)

results.title: Fires within
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Lauren Lloyd, Wallis Nicita and Pathe Entertainment
results.brief_description: When husband and wife Nestor (Jimmy Smits) and Isabel (Greta Scacchi) are reunited after Nestor is freed from jail for serving a 10 year term as a political prisoner they both find it hard to existence as husband and wife, living in Miami’s Little Havana. The community are eager for Nestor to resume his role as spokesperson for atrocities perpetrated by the Cuban government. His wife, Isabel (Greta Scacchi), does not want their lives or their families in Cuba sacrificed to the greater cause of freedom of expression. Isabel has also found love in the arms of the American fisherman who saved her and her daughter when they nearly drowned fleeing Cuba, and like her husband, she too must make a choice between her priorities as a lover, and as a wife and mother. Cast also includes Vincent D’Onofrio.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Lauren Lloyd, Wallis Nicita and Pathe Entertainment
results.description: When husband and wife Nestor (Jimmy Smits) and Isabel (Greta Scacchi) are reunited after Nestor is freed from jail for serving a 10 year term as a political prisoner they both find it hard to existence as husband and wife, living in Miami’s Little Havana. The community are eager for Nestor to resume his role as spokesperson for atrocities perpetrated by the Cuban government. His wife, Isabel (Greta Scacchi), does not want their lives or their families in Cuba sacrificed to the greater cause of freedom of expression. Isabel has also found love in the arms of the American fisherman who saved her and her daughter when they nearly drowned fleeing Cuba, and like her husband, she too must make a choice between her priorities as a lover, and as a wife and mother. Cast also includes Vincent D’Onofrio.

results.title: Braindead = Dead alive (D)
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Jim Booth and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: New Zealand director Peter Jackson has aptly described “Braindead’s” anarchic style as splatstick, an outrageous melding of extreme gore and physical humour. While it does go to great lengths to gross you out (you’ll never eat porridge again!), it still finds time to be a rather sweet love story, as well as a titanic Oedipal struggle between mother and son. Set in the latter part of the fifties, “Braindead” concerns momma’s boy Lionel’s (Timothy Balme) feeble attempts to break away from his domineering mother (Elizabeth Moody), while a romance develops between him and local shop girl, Paquita (Diana Penalver). The situation gets messy however when Lionel’s mother is bitten by a strange rat like monkey (captured in a very funny opening sequence) which turns her into one of the living dead. When Lionel’s lecherous uncle Les (Ian Watkin) shows up unexpectedly, all hell breaks loose and soon the place is swarming with zombies.
